entry.title: Highlights from Django: Under The Hood 2016
entry.content:
Description

Django: Under The Hood: http://djangounderthehood.com/

Django: Under The Hood is an annual Django conference for experienced Django developers. Come and learn about the internals of Django, and help to shape its future.

entry.title: Lightning Talks - Sept. 4, 2013
entry.summary:
Summary

LIGHTNING TALKS: Sept. 04, 2013

The annual tradition of lightning talks has captivated the Django world.

A lightning talk is a chance to say something to (a large subset of) the whole conference. The thing is, lightnings should last "a MAXIMUM of five minutes." Allowing a minute between talks …
entry.content:
Summary

LIGHTNING TALKS: Sept. 04, 2013

The annual tradition of lightning talks has captivated the Django world.

A lightning talk is a chance to say something to (a large subset of) the whole conference. The thing is, lightnings should last "a MAXIMUM of five minutes." Allowing a minute between talks, if each talk averaged THREE minutes there would be time for roughly forty-five talks. So please don't feel that you HAVE to speak for five minutes. Say what you have to say, and stop.

entry.content:
Description

LIGHTNING TALKS: Sept. 05, 2013

The annual tradition of lightning talks has captivated the Django world.

A lightning talk is a chance to say something to (a large subset of) the whole conference. The thing is, lightnings should last "a MAXIMUM of five minutes." Allowing a minute between talks, if each talk averaged THREE minutes there would be time for roughly forty-five talks. So please don't feel that you HAVE to speak for five minutes. Say what you have to say, and stop.

entry.title: Lightning Talks
entry.content:
Summary

A lightning talk is a short talk, typically only five minutes in duration, providing an opportunity for participants - particularly people not featured in the main programme - to deliver a presentation on a subject of their choosing.

entry.content:
Summary

Lightning talks at Kiwi PyCon 2013.

Description

@ Kiwi PyCon 2013 - Sunday, 08 Sep 2013 - Track 1

  1. Dylan Jay - Sweet Robot Suite - 0:27
  2. Thomi Richards - Secret Dunedin Cool Things - 5:05
  3. Clinton Roy - PyCon AU 2014/15 - 9:09
  4. Jürgen Brendel - Read-Optimise your Source Code - 11:30
  5. Anita Kean - Family Tree for the Family - 16:20
  6. James Mitchell - Motif, iCal, Sockets & Python - 23:15
  7. Aurynn Shaw - Why I Ruby or Please tell me I'm wrong - 26:57
  8. Peter Harrison - Shard Secret Sharing - 31:05
  9. Jonathan Harker - Digital Object Repositories - 35:08
  10. John Graves - Why most open source projects have only one developer - 38:45
  11. William McKee - Scalping Data ... JSON Processing (TradeMe, LastFM, Wordpress) - 43:33
  12. Larry Hastings - Go with the Grain or the Pickle - 45:44
  13. Tom Leys - How Gridspy uses Twisted and Django to deliver Real-Time - 49:45

entry.title: Charlas Relámpago (Sorpresa)
entry.content:
Description

PyconAR 2016 - Bahía Blanca

Charlas Relámpago (Sorpresa)

Luego de las charlas relámpago una de las participantes del evento pidió pasar al frente para comentar su experiencia en el evento, fue uno de los momentos más emotivos vivido por todos los participantes, previo al cierre de la PyconAR 2016.
